text: few people I've met are as diverse and
multilingual as the people of and that's
because there's no indigenous population
the locals are mostly descendants of
India France Great Britain Madagascar
and China their faces make up every
shape size and color and it's cool to
witness them all coexisting peacefully
as one nation as far as religion goes it
breaks down to about 15% Muslim 25%
Roman Catholic and 52% Hindu making
Mauritius the only country in Africa
with Hinduism as the main religion and
whenever one religion has a holiday the
entire country celebrates it like Diwali
or Christmas or the end of Ramadan
that's why there are about 20 holidays
every year in Mauritius their culture
and lifestyle has absorbed pieces from
their former colonization countries so
this is a Shiraz distillery where we
make work such as driving on the left
side of the road from the British
they're tasty spices from the Indians
and the foundation of their language
Creole from the French speaking of
languages almost everyone in Mauritius
speaks at least three languages fluently
Creole French and English and a fourth
is commonly spoken such as Hindi Tamil
or Mandarin but perhaps the best part
about Mauritius is diverse culture can
be seen in its food particularly street
food which CNN ranked as a top 10 best
in the world I shall in little rousseff
make by myself how many years have you
been cooking this food 60 years when I
am five years old I sit with my father
on the roadside hmm
at night every dish came here from
overseas mostly India or China or East
Africa and has transformed into its own
Mauritian style
that Chinese one sasame kid with sweet
potato rice flour and black lenses
Chinese chicken shoe shoe wrapped in
rice flour and fish board so now when
you think of Mauritius and its culture
don't forget about the diversity that
comes along with it
I'm German ski and if you like my travel
videos please click Subscribe and join
me as I plan to visit every country in
the world
